description: Borrowed from French gigot (“leg (of lamb)”), from gigue (“(colloquial) a long leg; haunch of some animals, especially venison”) + -ot (“diminutive suffix”). Gigue is derived from giguer (“to dance; to jump”), further etymology unknown.

entries.meaning: (cooking) A leg of lamb or mutton.
(fashion) Short for gigot sleeve (“a type of sleeve shaped like a leg of mutton”).
